LearnNonparam 1.2.1
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Examples

    Examples

    examples.Rmd
    library(LearnNonparam)

set.seed(2023)

    Chapter 1

    Example 1.1.2 

    # See ?Quantile or ?onesample.quantile
t <- pmt(
    "onesample.quantile", alternative = "greater",
    prob = 0.5, null_value = 75,
    type = "asymp", correct = FALSE
)

# See ?Table1.1.1
t$test(Table1.1.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 26
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.02888979
t$ci
#> [1] 75.0 77.1

    Example 1.2.1 

    # See ?CDF or ?onesample.cdf
t <- pmt("onesample.cdf")

# See ?Table1.2.1
t$test(Table1.2.1)

t$plot(style = "ggplot2")

    Example 1.2.4 

    # See ?Quantile or ?onesample.quantile
t <- pmt(
    "onesample.quantile",
    prob = 0.25, null_value = 0, conf_level = 0.90
)

# See ?Table1.2.1
t$test(Table1.2.1)

t$ci
#> [1] 11 29

    Chapter 2

    Table 2.1.1 

    # See ?Difference or ?twosample.difference
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.difference", alternative = "greater", method = "mean"
)

# See ?Table2.1.1
t$test(Table2.1.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 16.16667
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.05714286

    Table 2.1.1 - wilcoxon 

    # See ?Wilcoxon or ?twosample.wilcoxon
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.wilcoxon", alternative = "greater"
)

# See ?Table2.1.1
t$test(Table2.1.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 21
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.05714286

    Example 2.3.1 

    # See ?Difference or ?twosample.difference
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.difference", alternative = "greater", method = "mean"
)

# See ?Table2.3.1
t$test(Table2.3.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 1.675

# all permutaions
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.1966589

# 1000 permutaions
t$n_permu <- 1000
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.203

    Example 2.6.1 

    # See ?Wilcoxon or ?twosample.wilcoxon
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.wilcoxon", alternative = "greater"
)

# See ?Table2.6.1
t$test(Table2.6.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 14
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.9

    Example 2.6.2 

    # See ?Wilcoxon or ?twosample.wilcoxon
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.wilcoxon", conf_level = 0.90
)

# See ?Table2.6.2
t$test(Table2.6.2)

t$estimate
#> [1] 30.045
t$ci
#> [1] 13.84 47.96

    Example 2.7.1 

    # See ?ScoreSum or ?twosample.scoresum
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.scoresum", alternative = "greater", scoring = "expon"
)

# See ?Table2.6.2
t$test(Table2.6.2)

t$statistic
#> [1] 9.752597
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.002164502

    Example 2.8.1 

    # See ?SiegelTukey or ?twosample.siegel
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.siegel", alternative = "greater", type = "asymp"
)

# See ?Table2.8.1
t$test(Table2.8.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 24
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.2654347

    Example 2.8.2 

    # See ?RatioDifferenceDeviance or ?twosample.rmd
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.rmd", alternative = "greater"
)

# See ?Table2.8.1
t$test(Table2.8.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 4.666667
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.06349206

    Example 2.8.3 

    # See ?KolmogorovSmirnov or ?twosample.ks
t <- pmt("twosample.ks")

# See ?Table2.8.1
t$test(Table2.8.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 0.4
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.8730159

    Chapter 3

    Example 3.1.1 

    # See ?KSampleF or ?ksample.f
t <- pmt(
    "ksample.f", type = "asymp"
)

# See ?Table3.1.2
t$test(Table3.1.2)

t$statistic
#> [1] 3.781445
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.05327082

t$type <- "permu"

t$statistic
#> [1] 11552.89
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.05127412

    Example 3.2.1 

    # See ?KruskalWallis or ?ksample.kw
t <- pmt(
    "ksample.kw", type = "asymp"
)

# See ?Table3.2.2
t$test(Table3.2.2)

t$statistic
#> [1] 17.14286
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.0006605027

    Example 3.2.2 

    # See ?KruskalWallis or ?ksample.kw
t <- pmt(
    "ksample.kw", n_permu = 4000
)

# See ?Table3.2.3
t$test(Table3.2.3)

t$statistic
#> [1] 8.246588
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.01025


t$type <- "asymp"
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.01619109

    Example 3.3.1 

    # See ?Studentized or ?multicomp.studentized
t <- pmt(
    "multicomp.studentized", n_permu = 5000, method = "bonferroni"
)

# See ?Table3.3.1
t$test(Table3.3.1)

t$print()
#> 
#>   Multiple Comparison Based on Studentized Statistic 
#> 
#> scoring: none    type: permu(5000)    method: bonferroni
#> 
#> family-wise confidence level: 95%
#> 
#>                           statistic p-value  
#> location_1 ~ location_2  0.02737145  0.9744  
#> location_1 ~ location_3 -1.77914406  0.0888  
#> location_1 ~ location_4 -3.41048230  0.0034 *
#> location_2 ~ location_3 -1.80651550  0.0900  
#> location_2 ~ location_4 -3.43785375  0.0030 *
#> location_3 ~ location_4 -1.63133824  0.1254

t$type <- "asymp"
t$print()
#> 
#>   Multiple Comparison Based on Studentized Statistic 
#> 
#> scoring: none    type: asymp    method: bonferroni
#> 
#> family-wise confidence level: 95%
#> 
#>                           statistic     p-value  
#> location_1 ~ location_2  0.02737145 0.978434752  
#> location_1 ~ location_3 -1.77914406 0.090419680  
#> location_1 ~ location_4 -3.41048230 0.002773484 *
#> location_2 ~ location_3 -1.80651550 0.085909110  
#> location_2 ~ location_4 -3.43785375 0.002603664 *
#> location_3 ~ location_4 -1.63133824 0.118466249

t$scoring <- "rank"
t$print()
#> 
#>   Multiple Comparison Based on Studentized Statistic 
#> 
#> scoring: rank    type: asymp    method: bonferroni
#> 
#> family-wise confidence level: 95%
#> 
#>                          statistic     p-value  
#> location_1 ~ location_2  0.1224745 0.902523250  
#> location_1 ~ location_3 -1.3880442 0.165123590  
#> location_1 ~ location_4 -2.6536139 0.007963489 *
#> location_2 ~ location_3 -1.5105187 0.130911128  
#> location_2 ~ location_4 -2.7760884 0.005501725 *
#> location_3 ~ location_4 -1.2655697 0.205667180


t$method <- "tukey"
t$print()
#> 
#>   Multiple Comparison Based on Studentized Statistic 
#> 
#> scoring: rank    type: asymp    method: tukey
#> 
#> family-wise confidence level: 95%
#> 
#>                         statistic    p-value  
#> location_1 ~ location_2 0.1732051 0.99934385  
#> location_1 ~ location_3 1.9629909 0.50683497  
#> location_1 ~ location_4 3.7527767 0.03978340 *
#> location_2 ~ location_3 2.1361960 0.43109997  
#> location_2 ~ location_4 3.9259818 0.02817015 *
#> location_3 ~ location_4 1.7897858 0.58494735

t$scoring <- "none"
t$print()
#> 
#>   Multiple Comparison Based on Studentized Statistic 
#> 
#> scoring: none    type: asymp    method: tukey
#> 
#> family-wise confidence level: 95%
#> 
#>                          statistic    p-value  
#> location_1 ~ location_2 0.03870907 0.99999236  
#> location_1 ~ location_3 2.51608965 0.31194094  
#> location_1 ~ location_4 4.82315032 0.01356971 *
#> location_2 ~ location_3 2.55479873 0.29951264  
#> location_2 ~ location_4 4.86185939 0.01277452 *
#> location_3 ~ location_4 2.30706067 0.38453323

t$type <- "permu"
t$print()
#> 
#>   Multiple Comparison Based on Studentized Statistic 
#> 
#> scoring: none    type: permu(5000)    method: tukey
#> 
#> family-wise confidence level: 95%
#> 
#>                          statistic p-value  
#> location_1 ~ location_2 0.03870907  1.0000  
#> location_1 ~ location_3 2.51608965  0.3004  
#> location_1 ~ location_4 4.82315032  0.0152 *
#> location_2 ~ location_3 2.55479873  0.2876  
#> location_2 ~ location_4 4.86185939  0.0142 *
#> location_3 ~ location_4 2.30706067  0.3700

    Example 3.4.1 

    # See ?JonckheereTerpstra or ?ksample.jt
t <- pmt(
    "ksample.jt", alternative = "greater", n_permu = 4000
)

# See ?Table3.4.1
t$test(Table3.4.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 145
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.03225

t$type <- "asymp"
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.0285154

    Chapter 4

    Table 4.1.1 

    # See ?PairedDifference or ?paired.difference
t <- pmt(
    "paired.difference", alternative = "greater",
    scoring = "none"
)

# See ?Table4.1.1
t$test(Table4.1.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 960
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.09375

    Example 4.1.1 

    # See ?PairedDifference or ?paired.difference
t <- pmt(
    "paired.difference", alternative = "two_sided",
    scoring = "none", method = "without_zeros"
)

# See ?Table4.1.3
t$test(Table4.1.3)

t$statistic
#> [1] 148
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.02502441

t$n_permu <- 4000
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.029

t$type <- "asymp"
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.0267714

    Example 4.2.1 & 4.2.2 

    # See ?PairedDifference or ?paired.difference
t <- pmt(
    "paired.difference", alternative = "greater",
    scoring = "rank", method = "with_zeros"
)

# See ?Table4.1.1
t$test(Table4.1.1)

t$statistic
#> [1] 13
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.09375

t$type <- "asymp"
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.08876493

    Example 4.3.1 

    # See ?Sign or ?paired.sign
t <- pmt(
    "paired.sign", alternative = "greater", type = "exact"
)

t$test(
    rep(c(+1, -1), c(12, 5)),
    rep(0, 17)
)

t$statistic
#> [1] 12
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.07173157

t$type <- "asymp"
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.07280505

    Example 4.4.1 

    # See ?RCBDF or ?rcbd.f
t <- pmt(
    "rcbd.f", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table4.4.3
t$test(Table4.4.3)

t$statistic
#> [1] 110241.8
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.118

t$type <- "asymp"
t$statistic
#> [1] 3.121093
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.057516

    Example 4.5.2 

    # See ?Friedman or ?rcbd.friedman
t <- pmt(
    "rcbd.friedman", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table4.5.3
t$test(Table4.5.3)

t$statistic
#> [1] 28.33333
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.0402

t$type <- "asymp"
t$statistic
#> [1] 7.5
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.05755845

    Example 4.6.1 

    # See ?Page or ?rcbd.page
t <- pmt(
    "rcbd.page", alternative = "less", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table4.4.3
t$test(Table4.4.3)

t$statistic
#> [1] 134
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.0108

t$type <- "asymp"
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.01182581

    Chapter 5

    Example 5.1.1 

    # See ?Correlation or ?association.corr
t <- pmt(
    "association.corr", method = "pearson",
    alternative = "greater", n_permu = 2000
)

# See ?Table5.1.2
t$test(Table5.1.2)

t$statistic
#> [1] 198766597
t$p_value
#> [1] 0

    Example 5.2.1 

    # See ?Correlation or ?association.corr
t <- pmt(
    "association.corr", method = "spearman",
    alternative = "two_sided", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table5.1.2
t$test(Table5.1.2)

t$statistic
#> [1] 2059
t$p_value
#> [1] 0

t$type <- "asymp"
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.0002176436

    Example 5.3.2 

    # See ?Correlation or ?association.corr
t <- pmt(
    "association.corr", method = "kendall",
    alternative = "greater", type = "asymp"
)

# See ?Table5.2.2
t$test(Table5.2.2)

t$statistic
#> [1] 0.2222222
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.1697136

    Table 5.4.2 

    # See ?ChiSquare or ?table.chisq
t <- pmt("table.chisq")

# See ?Table5.4.2
t$test(Table5.4.2)

t$statistic
#> [1] 4.277778
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.3142857

t$type <- "asymp"
t$p_value
#> [1] 0.1177856
